column4: it was giving him a token error so i said sudo passwd username
that can lead to *big* troubles with an encrypted home directory !

the password is used to gain access to the encrypted passphrase for decrypting the home directory - if a user changes it herself that process is adapted as well. If root does it the connection is lost and if she hasn't recorded her passphrase she will never be able to access her data
who would forget their passphrase? :P
I beg your pardon? the initially set passphrase is a 50 character random string
when you log in for the first time it prompts you to change it

you have obviously never installed the system with "encrypted home directory" . you should not change the passphrase but record it and store it in a safe place. the encryption needs a *very* strong password to be of any value
actually my home directory is encrypted right now.
did you record the passphrase? (I have no idea how to change it, I admit)
no i made it my normal password. i would never record 50 digit anything. not even my wpa password :P
I think we are talking about different things here  - the long passphrase is actually the encryption key, it *must* be long and should be random
its possible. i am pretty sure its the right thing
can you tell me (in short) or point me to some docu what you did to change it?
when i booted after install a terminal popped up asking me to change it
on plain ubuntu?
64 bit, yeah
i think if you forget it youre screwed
well, my experience differs greatly here - and mind you a "short" encryption key won't protect you very well
the only thing i am hiding it porn. and its not embarrassing porn so if you can get by encrypted file system then you can get in
I really don't care about your data - but please don't give potentially harmful advice
i still dont understand what's so harmful about it

once again: as long as you access your system with "your" password it is used to decrypt the encryption key, so you have access to your data. That remains so when you change your password yourself. but when "root" does it the chain is broken (or when you lose your system)
so what should he do when using passwd as a user gives him a token error?
he gets that error with sudo too ( if I remember correctly ) - something in the system must be broken - that should be investigated
